title: Chinese Embassy donates office equipment to Republican Hospital and Capital Chamber of Commerce and Industry in Sana’a
description: According to an article publish by China’s Ministry of Commerce (MOFOM), the Chinese embassy in Yemen donated office equipment of an unspecified amount and type to the Republic Hospital (هيئة المستشفى الجمهوري التعليمي في صنعاء) and the Capital Chamber of Commerce and Industry in the capital city of Sana’a in 2008. The ceremony for the handover of the materials was held on December 23, 2008.

title: Chinese Government sponsors training of Yemeni officials
description: On July 29 and August 6, 2008, the Chinese and Yemeni governments signed an letters of exchange agreeing to organize a seminar on bilateral management cadres for Yemeni government officials in China.   On October 10th, 2008, 36 officials from the Ministry of Planning and International Cooperation, the Ministry of Finance, and other unspecified ministries left for China. The visiting delegation attended seminars on Chinese development, bilateral cooperation, and management. They also visited major cities such as Jiangsu and Shanghai. The actual end date of the visiting is vague.
combined_text:
# Sector
GOVERNMENT AND CIVIL SOCIETY

# Title

# Description

On October 10th, 2008, 36 officials from the Ministry of Planning and International Cooperation, the Ministry of Finance, and other unspecified ministries left for China. The visiting delegation attended seminars on Chinese development, bilateral cooperation, and management. They also visited major cities such as Jiangsu and Shanghai. The actual end date of the visiting is vague.
justification: Project focuses on capacity building and knowledge sharing without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Training seminar for government officials, focus on development and management topics

title: Chinese Government provides RMB 5 million grant for Taiz Rural School Construction Project
description: On June 24, 2008, the Chinese Embassy in Yemen and the Yemeni Government signed letters of exchange, which committed RMB 5 million (or $700,000) grant agreement for the Taiz Rural School Construction Project. China’s Ministry of Commerce (MOFCOM) was the source of funding.   This project involved the construction of a primary school with 15 classrooms in Saber al-Mawadim (صبر الموادم) district within Taiz Governorate. A construction contract was issued to Sinohydro Corporation Ltd. on April 13, 2010 in Sana'a. The project commenced on May 30, 2010 and ended on January 10, 2011. It passed final MOFCOM inspection on January 15, 2012.
staff_comments: The Chinese project title is 也门塔兹农村学校
combined_text:
# Sector
EDUCATION

# Title
Chinese Government provides RMB 5 million grant for Taiz Rural School Construction Project

# Description
On June 24, 2008, the Chinese Embassy in Yemen and the Yemeni Government signed letters of exchange, which committed RMB 5 million (or $700,000) grant agreement for the Taiz Rural School Construction Project. China’s Ministry of Commerce (MOFCOM) was the source of funding.   This project involved the construction of a primary school with 15 classrooms in Saber al-Mawadim (صبر الموادم) district within Taiz Governorate. A construction contract was issued to Sinohydro Corporation Ltd. on April 13, 2010 in Sana'a. The project commenced on May 30, 2010 and ended on January 10, 2011. It passed final MOFCOM inspection on January 15, 2012.
justification: Project focuses on education infrastructure without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Construction of primary school with 15 classrooms, education sector focus

title: China Eximbank provides $315 million loan for 360MW Kariba North Bank Hydropower Plant Expansion Project
description: In October 2008, China Eximbank and Kariba North Bank Extension Power Corporation Limited (KNBEPCL) — a special purpose vehicle and wholly-owned subsidiary of Zambia Electricity Supply Corporation (ZESCO) Limited, a state-owned power company in Zambia — signed a $315 million loan agreement for the 360MW Kariba North Bank Hydropower Plant Expansion Project. KNBEPCL is a project company and a wholly owned subsidiary of ZESCO Limited, Zambia’s state-owned power company. The China Eximbank loan to KNBEPCL carried the following borrowing terms: a 15 year maturity an interest rate of LIBOR plus 200 basis points. The loan’s amount outstanding was $268 million as of December 31, 2015, $240.9 million as of December 31, 2016, $214.2 million as of December 31, 2017, $214.2 million as of December 31, 2018, $160.62 million as of December 31, 2019, $133.848 million os of December 31, 2020, $120,464,052 as of June 30, 2021, and $100,002,768 (inclusive of $6,308,506 in interest arrears) as of June 30, 2022.    The loan was secured by (collateralized against) receivables from Copperbelt Energy Corporation and Chambeshi Mining Company. The proceeds from this loan were used to be used by the borrower to finance an EPC contract between Sinohydro and ZESCO Limited, which was signed on November 15, 2007. Development Bank of South Africa also provided a $105 million loan for the same project. This project involved an expansion of the power generation capacity of the Kariba North hydroelectric power station through the installation of two new generators. Construction began on November 5, 2008. However, the project encountered a number of problems and delays. In 2009, a fire broke out in one of the generators. Then, in November 2011, it was reported that project completion had been delayed a year due to 'financial constraints'.   The project was ultimately completed on August 21, 2014. An official completion ceremony took place on August 27, 2014. The 1.08GW Kariba North hydroelectric power station is located on the bank of Zambezi River at Kariba in the southern province of Zambia. It includes the Kariba North Bank (KNB) (720MW) power plant and the Kariba North Bank Extension (KNBE) (360MW) power plant. The KNB power plant was developed between 1969 and 1976 as part of the Central African Power Corporation’s (CAPC) development program. The KNBE power plant consists of two 180MW vertical-shaft Francis turbines with a rated discharge 227.6m3/s operating at a head of 89m for each single unit. It has two intake chambers for water at an elevation of 458m. The underground powerhouse is 24m wide and 51m in length. The power generated is transmitted through a 130 km long, 330kV transmission line from the KNBE power plant to the existing Kafue west substation. The power generated from KNBE is purchased by ZESCO Limited under a 20-year long-term power purchase agreement (PPA), which was approved by Zambia’s Energy Regulation Board (ERB) in April 2011.
staff_comments: 1. The Chinese project title is 赞比亚卡里巴北岸水电站扩机工程 or 卡里巴北岸电站2X180MW or 在赞比亚卡里巴北岸水电站扩机项目. 2. AidData estimates the all-in interest rate (5.878%) by calculating the average 6-month LIBOR rate in the month when the loan was originally contracted (0.517%) and adding a 2% margin. 3. Some sources suggest the the loan agreement was signed in November 2009 rather than October 2008. This issue warrants further investigation.
combined_text:
# Sector
ENERGY

# Title
China Eximbank provides $315 million loan for 360MW Kariba North Bank Hydropower Plant Expansion Project

# Description
In October 2008, China Eximbank and Kariba North Bank Extension Power Corporation Limited (KNBEPCL) — a special purpose vehicle and wholly-owned subsidiary of Zambia Electricity Supply Corporation (ZESCO) Limited, a state-owned power company in Zambia — signed a $315 million loan agreement for the 360MW Kariba North Bank Hydropower Plant Expansion Project. KNBEPCL is a project company and a wholly owned subsidiary of ZESCO Limited, Zambia’s state-owned power company. The China Eximbank loan to KNBEPCL carried the following borrowing terms: a 15 year maturity an interest rate of LIBOR plus 200 basis points. The loan’s amount outstanding was $268 million as of December 31, 2015, $240.9 million as of December 31, 2016, $214.2 million as of December 31, 2017, $214.2 million as of December 31, 2018, $160.62 million as of December 31, 2019, $133.848 million os of December 31, 2020, $120,464,052 as of June 30, 2021, and $100,002,768 (inclusive of $6,308,506 in interest arrears) as of June 30, 2022.    The loan was secured by (collateralized against) receivables from Copperbelt Energy Corporation and Chambeshi Mining Company. The proceeds from this loan were used to be used by the borrower to finance an EPC contract between Sinohydro and ZESCO Limited, which was signed on November 15, 2007. Development Bank of South Africa also provided a $105 million loan for the same project. This project involved an expansion of the power generation capacity of the Kariba North hydroelectric power station through the installation of two new generators. Construction began on November 5, 2008. However, the project encountered a number of problems and delays. In 2009, a fire broke out in one of the generators. Then, in November 2011, it was reported that project completion had been delayed a year due to 'financial constraints'.   The project was ultimately completed on August 21, 2014. An official completion ceremony took place on August 27, 2014. The 1.08GW Kariba North hydroelectric power station is located on the bank of Zambezi River at Kariba in the southern province of Zambia. It includes the Kariba North Bank (KNB) (720MW) power plant and the Kariba North Bank Extension (KNBE) (360MW) power plant. The KNB power plant was developed between 1969 and 1976 as part of the Central African Power Corporation’s (CAPC) development program. The KNBE power plant consists of two 180MW vertical-shaft Francis turbines with a rated discharge 227.6m3/s operating at a head of 89m for each single unit. It has two intake chambers for water at an elevation of 458m. The underground powerhouse is 24m wide and 51m in length. The power generated is transmitted through a 130 km long, 330kV transmission line from the KNBE power plant to the existing Kafue west substation. The power generated from KNBE is purchased by ZESCO Limited under a 20-year long-term power purchase agreement (PPA), which was approved by Zambia’s Energy Regulation Board (ERB) in April 2011.
justification: Primary purpose is expansion of hydroelectric power generation capacity, a renewable energy source
evidence: 360MW hydropower plant expansion, installation of two new generators, renewable energy focus

title: Chinese Governments provides 46 government scholarships to students from Zambia in 2008-2009
description: On August 21, 2008, the Chinese Ambassador to Zambia hosted a farewell reception for 46 Zambian students who the Chinese Government awarded the 2008-2009 government scholarships to. The value of each scholarship is unknown. The 46 students were to study in various universities in China. They planned to study computer science, mechanical engineering, medicine, and other majors.
combined_text:
# Sector
EDUCATION

# Title
Chinese Governments provides 46 government scholarships to students from Zambia in 2008-2009

# Description
On August 21, 2008, the Chinese Ambassador to Zambia hosted a farewell reception for 46 Zambian students who the Chinese Government awarded the 2008-2009 government scholarships to. The value of each scholarship is unknown. The 46 students were to study in various universities in China. They planned to study computer science, mechanical engineering, medicine, and other majors.
justification: Scholarship program focused on education and human development without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: 46 government scholarships for Zambian students to study various majors in China

title: Chinese Government provides $2.5 million interest-free loan for critical underfunded areas
description: On 23 February, 2008, the Chinese Government signed an interest-free loan agreement worth $2.5 million with the Government of Zimbabwe for 'critical areas that need funds'.  The Chinese Government was represented by Vice Minister of Commerce, Gao Hucheng, at the signing ceremony while the Zimbabwean Government was represented by the Acting Minister of Finance and Minister of Industry and Internatioanl Trade, Obert Mpofu.  Information on the final disbursement of these funds and the relevant dates of implementation is uncertain.
staff_comments: Since loan terms for the interest-free loan are unavailable, AidData has set maturity period to 20 years by default and grace period to 10 years by default per China's Foreign Assistance White Paper (http://www.cidca.gov.cn/2018-08/06/c_129925064_3.htm) which states that the maturity period of interest-free loans is 20 years, with a drawdown period of 5 years, grace period of 5 years, and repayment over 10 years. AidData treats the drawdown period as providing 5 years of additional grace.
combined_text:
# Sector
GOVERNMENT AND CIVIL SOCIETY

# Title
Chinese Government provides $2.5 million interest-free loan for critical underfunded areas

# Description
On 23 February, 2008, the Chinese Government signed an interest-free loan agreement worth $2.5 million with the Government of Zimbabwe for 'critical areas that need funds'.  The Chinese Government was represented by Vice Minister of Commerce, Gao Hucheng, at the signing ceremony while the Zimbabwean Government was represented by the Acting Minister of Finance and Minister of Industry and Internatioanl Trade, Obert Mpofu.  Information on the final disbursement of these funds and the relevant dates of implementation is uncertain.
justification: Loan agreement for general funding purposes without specific environmental or energy-related focus
evidence: Interest-free loan for 'critical areas that need funds', no specific project details provided

title: Chinese Government dispatches 11th medical team to Harare Central Hospital and Mpilo Central Hospital
description: On March 6, 2008, the Chinese Government and the Government of Zimbabwe signed letters of exchange, officially dispatching the 11th medical team to Zimbabwe. The 11th medical team consisted of 10 members. They were stationed at Harare Central Hospital and Mpilo Central Hospital.  They completed their term of service between May 2008 and 2010.  The Chinese Government has been sending medical teams to Zimbabwe every two years since 1985.  Hunan Province has been responsible for sending the teams.
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Description
On March 6, 2008, the Chinese Government and the Government of Zimbabwe signed letters of exchange, officially dispatching the 11th medical team to Zimbabwe. The 11th medical team consisted of 10 members. They were stationed at Harare Central Hospital and Mpilo Central Hospital.  They completed their term of service between May 2008 and 2010.  The Chinese Government has been sending medical teams to Zimbabwe every two years since 1985.  Hunan Province has been responsible for sending the teams.
justification: Project is focused on healthcare services with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Medical team deployment to hospitals, healthcare sector focus

title: Coalition formed by Chinese companies donates goods to Zimbabwean trust
description: As part of a multi-million dollar aid program to help 3,000 people infected with HIV/AIDS in Zimbabwe, seven Chinese companies have donated  basic goods worth over US $5 000 to Mashambanzou Trust in Waterfalls, Harare. The goods included beef, cooking oil, flour, bread, Colgate toothpaste, tomatoes, eggs, maize meal, drinks and bicycles.Speaking at the launch of Care Action in Harare yesterday, Chinese Ambassador to ZimbabweMr Yuan Nansheng said the project would assist the disadvantaged and those affected and infected by HIV and Aids in Zimbabwe.The companies are - Sinosteel Zimbabwe, Tianze Tobacco, Sino-Africa Nickels, China Jiangxi Corporation, Huawei Technologies, Zimbabwe International Travel and Tourism and Connick Investments. Mr Yuan said the action would be coordinated by the Zimbabwean Chinese funded Enterprises' Association and the Chinese Businessmen's Association. He said the companies would also motivate more firms from the Far Eastern country to assist Zimbabwe.
staff_comments: Transaction value amount not recorded because amount from Chinese OF agencies was not distinguishable from private companies.
combined_text:
# Sector
DEVELOPMENTAL FOOD AID/FOOD SECURITY ASSISTANCE

# Title
Coalition formed by Chinese companies donates goods to Zimbabwean trust

# Description
As part of a multi-million dollar aid program to help 3,000 people infected with HIV/AIDS in Zimbabwe, seven Chinese companies have donated  basic goods worth over US $5 000 to Mashambanzou Trust in Waterfalls, Harare. The goods included beef, cooking oil, flour, bread, Colgate toothpaste, tomatoes, eggs, maize meal, drinks and bicycles.Speaking at the launch of Care Action in Harare yesterday, Chinese Ambassador to ZimbabweMr Yuan Nansheng said the project would assist the disadvantaged and those affected and infected by HIV and Aids in Zimbabwe.The companies are - Sinosteel Zimbabwe, Tianze Tobacco, Sino-Africa Nickels, China Jiangxi Corporation, Huawei Technologies, Zimbabwe International Travel and Tourism and Connick Investments. Mr Yuan said the action would be coordinated by the Zimbabwean Chinese funded Enterprises' Association and the Chinese Businessmen's Association. He said the companies would also motivate more firms from the Far Eastern country to assist Zimbabwe.
justification: Project focuses on humanitarian aid and social development without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Food aid and basic goods donation to support HIV/AIDS affected population, coordinated by Chinese companies and associations

title: Chinese Government provides $500,000 cash grant for acquisition of cholera vaccines to Zimbabwe in 2008
description: On November 27, 2008, the Chinese government signed an agreement pledging US$500,000 worth of cholera vaccines and food aid to Zimbabwe. This donation was in response to an outbreak of cholera that killed around 400 Zimbabweans in the previous weeks.  On December 23, 2008, the donation of vaccines was changed to USD $500,000 in cash intended for the Zimbabwean government to purchase the vaccines directly from suppliers after technical problems in the distribution and storage of the original vaccine donation. On this day, the donation was handed over to Zimbabwe at the Ministry of Health of Zimbabwe. The Government of China was represented by the Deputy Head of Mission in Zimbabwe, He Meng, and the Government of Zimbabwe was represented by the Minister of Health, David Parirenyatwa. This project is completed. This project is captured in UNOCHA Financial Tracking Services as Flow ID #61653.
combined_text:
# Sector
EMERGENCY RESPONSE

# Title
Chinese Government provides $500,000 cash grant for acquisition of cholera vaccines to Zimbabwe in 2008

# Description
On November 27, 2008, the Chinese government signed an agreement pledging US$500,000 worth of cholera vaccines and food aid to Zimbabwe. This donation was in response to an outbreak of cholera that killed around 400 Zimbabweans in the previous weeks.  On December 23, 2008, the donation of vaccines was changed to USD $500,000 in cash intended for the Zimbabwean government to purchase the vaccines directly from suppliers after technical problems in the distribution and storage of the original vaccine donation. On this day, the donation was handed over to Zimbabwe at the Ministry of Health of Zimbabwe. The Government of China was represented by the Deputy Head of Mission in Zimbabwe, He Meng, and the Government of Zimbabwe was represented by the Minister of Health, David Parirenyatwa. This project is completed. This project is captured in UNOCHA Financial Tracking Services as Flow ID #61653.
justification: Project is focused on healthcare and emergency response, with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Cash grant for cholera vaccines, healthcare focus, emergency response context
